column1: Will North Korea conduct a nuclear test before 1 January 2020?
column6: ['Security and Conflict']
column11: Past examples of North Korean nuclear tests include those listed here: BBC, NY Times. Confused? Check our FAQ or ask us for help.

column6: Doesn't look like they are ready again for nuclear test. Still there is a chance of conducting ICBM but less & less of that as we are coming closer to year-end.
Basically we are less than one week away, and after reading all the comments from the people I am following it seems pretty unlikely.
They havenÂ´t done so for a long time, why should they ruin Trumps christmas party now?
Fin.
The easiest option is an ICBM test, not a nuclear currently.

Criticism from DPRK Foreign Minister on Nov 17 after receiving signals from the US about another DJ-KJ meeting : "We will no longer give the US president something to boast about for nothing in return." I think it's more than that - they want legitimacy, something Trump opened the door to in 2018, but hasn't yet delivered. Can't think of a better way for KJ to grab DJ's attention than to light up a Yuletime nuke.
Will North Korea conduct a nuclear test before 1 January 2020? The US has agreed to stand down joint exercises.
Down from 5% due to passage of time and the North Korean year-end "deadline" of sorts.

KJ is the kind of guy that wants the world's attention. He's been out of the klieg lights for too long, with nothing to show for it. And KJ hasn't been feeling the love from the President in 2019. A Thanksgiving surprise would be directed at the US to take notice of the DPRK. A Christmas surprise would be directed at the world to take notice of the DPRK.

I found an error in my simulation spreadsheet when generating a similar prediction for the US democratic candidate drop outs. As of today, the simulation gives 6.5% chance. This will decrease almost 1% per week that passes without a new test. I'll keep an eye on updating this one.
They have conducted six tests since 2006 (last one in 2017), giving a base rate of about 1 every 2 years, or one every six months, +/-.
Adjusting down

Outside view suggests we're due for a test: They've detonated 6 bombs over 13 years, or one roughly every 2 years. The last one was in September of 2017, more than 2 years ago. However, based on analysis by @Anneinak and @Raahul_Kumar, it seems that they lack the infrastructure to continue testing at that pace. Thus, lowering estimate. Slightly extremizing crowd forecast.
Everyone is playing nice for the moment, I don't think Kim has anything to gain by provoking the US in such a dramatic fashion.
I anticipated tests of missile systems... nuclear tests will not come unless the relationship between trump and kim breaks down... highly unlikely

The other day I saw a headline that said that DPRK might be able to resurrect its old nuke test site. The article was behind a paywall, so I gave up on it. Has anyone read anything about that? Did it seem credible? Was there any suggestion about how long it would take to make it operational?
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/10/north-korea-threatens-resume-nuclear-long-range-missile-tests-191010091337349.html Probably an ICBM test instead of this.

This month's sea-based launch was coupled with a yet-again failed negotiation from DPRK's seat. I feel that KJ feels the need to grab Trump's attention. Although to what constructive purpose is not in evidence.
45-60 days.

Bumping up slightly as they just launched a Medium Range Ballistic Missile. Its possible Kim conducts a test before the new negotiations or in the event they break down. However, doing so would identify a new test facility to the world.

Adjusting down for the passage of time. Trumps response to Kim is one of steady contact, but little compromise. This sort of acknowledgement seems to please Kim. Further, China is likely to be applying more pressure to North Korea so as not to create another variable in trade talks.
Not this year, still trying to figure out Trump.

KJ will probably content himself with missile launches to stay on Trump's radar-of-importance. With Bolton gone - WH goes back to dovish. Seeing how Trump turned his heels on the Taliban - KJ doesn't want to invite rockets/missiles from having dissed DJT - and especially as uber-hawk Bolton is gone.
Trade war not resolved. North Korea is pro Beijing.
Long overdue.
~30 days.
Nuclear test are rare even for North Korea and they are on talks with Trump administration but it has been awhile since there last test so they may be ready to test new technology or techniques.

As I understand it the nuclear facility is out of commission and would take too long to get back up to speed to fit this timeframe. Nuclear weapons are easy in theory but the practice is hard. N Korea has demonstrated that it can produce weapons but is likely to concentrate more on delivery means - hence missile tests are more of a priority than reconstructing nuclear facility and detonating a bomb.

They may continue to test missiles but the bromance with Trump will endure throughout this period. Kims ambitions as reported by people who helped raise him are to be like China - an industrial powrhouse that makes money from trade. Getting the bomb was about self preservation. Besides he already has nuclear weapons that work
They already have so far in 2019.
To push Trumpâs buttons.

China don't want more 'waves' at the moment - they have their eyes on settling trade with USA and dealign with Trump. Kim won't gain much from test at the moment as it is likely to put China in a difficult position by giving USA Moral ammunition and leverage.
history and audacity
If North Korea does a nuclear test there will be no going back to diplomacy and I dont think they are willing to take that step right now
Nah, everything to load nothing to gain
https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/nation/2019/08/356_274460.html
~14 days.
List of nuclear weapons tests of North Korea https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_nuclear_weapons_tests_of_North_Korea
North Korea will do everything but a nuclear test.
No real reason to as of late and Kim jongâs new missile system seems to be keeping him occupied.
He may be mad, but he's not stupid.
https://www.npr.org/2019/07/29/746060429/despite-loss-of-faith-in-kim-jong-un-the-u-s-tries-again-for-a-nuclear-deal
Another one?!?

...Nuclear activity appears to be continuing, however, and satellite images of North Korea's main nuclear site last month showed movement, suggesting the country could be reprocessing radioactive material into bomb fuel....

Launch of short range ballistic missiles is an escalation. Further escalations possible? From: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-projectile/nuclear-talks-in-doubt-as-north-korea-tests-ballistic-missiles-envoy-cancels-trip-idUSKCN1UJ302: "North Koreaâs foreign ministry accused Washington this month of breaking a promise by holding military exercises with South Korea. On Tuesday, Kim inspected a large, newly built submarine from which ballistic missiles could be launched. âBy firing missiles, taking issue with military drills and showing a new submarine, the North is sending one clear message: there might be no working-level talks if the United States doesnât present a more flexible stance,â said Kim Hong-kyun, a former South Korean nuclear envoy."

It really depends on how much fissionable/fusionable material they hold I think. The Regime certainly needs it but they need a credible arsenal as well. I have no idea how much fissionable/fusionable they hold
Kim Jong-Un won't launch an ICBM but will do a test, just to show he can.
Interest
Something will come up requiring a show of independence.
Have really made no attempt to do anything except use Trump's visit for propaganda purposes. Once exhausted, the dictator must show strength as his predecessor was so fond of doing.

They are going nowhere and the trump administration has nothing to offer And, as a State actor, the have the right to "protect" themselves from hostile foreign forces International Political Theory 101
OH ~ 30 days.
Down from 6% due to passage of time and recent increase in friendly noises, including impromptu meeting between DJT and KJU, with possibility of third summit mentioned.
No need now.
- they won't risk the gain they have made with trump's recognition and relatively positive attitude towards their regime

rather unlikely, as the diplomatic fallout would be huge, while the current talks/commuication between the us and north korea could regain momentum (so no dramatic gesture = nuclear test needed to get attention)
I think he will, China is backing NK.
because bbc are a 'news' outlet.... so is a sure thing, true or not
Has not happened yet and time is running out beside it looks like the leadership in North Korea is not trying to rock the boat now too much
No reason they shouldnât from their POV.

The 6 known test are spread over 13 years with half of those in a short period in 2016-17. Though a bit unorthodox, meetings with Russia, China and US diminish the needs to test since Kim is gaining visibility.
Xi meeting Kim. Cool down.
I think Jong-un feels Trump is his best bet for him. Trump loves him, right. No other American POTUS has loved a North Korean dictator.

Missiles get enough attention for rocketman. Nuclear tests arenât cheap and when 40% of country suffers from food insecurity youâre much better off investing in Rolls Royceâs, vodka and caviar. His position isnât that secure - he has Pyongyang elite to keep comfortable . https://www.topspeed.com/cars/car-news/it-looks-like-north-korea-s-kim-jong-un-swapped-his-mercedes-for-a-new-rolls-royce-phantom-ar182927.html
They will do it as part of a political effort to damage Trump's election prospects. This will backfire since the American people see him as a strong defender.
Most likely.
Too much is at stake for this level of activity. The current food shortages, need for aid prevent this response. Other testing will continue but weapons with more limited capability.
they're busy testing solid rocket fuel performance and guidance.

North Korea can conduct a nuclear test if the US fails to meet the demands such as recalling the countryâs nuclear plan in South Korea and the assurance that the US will not start a nuclear strike on North Korea.

As others here have pointed out, there have been six tests since 2006. [1] For a base rate one would have to know since when they've had nuclear capability. Probably they did not wait very long with the first test. Assuming 2005 gives a base rate of 6/14=~43%.

North Korea has conducted six nuclear tests, in 2006, 2009, 2013, twice in 2016, and in 2017. While the pace of testing has sped up, North Korea has taken apart some of its nuclear sights, taken part in high level talks with the United States, and has been working to improve relations with South Korea. It is very unlikely that North Korea will take any action that will harm their standing in negotiations with South Korea or the United States. Barring any major fallout from peace talks the North Koreans have few incentives to conduct a nuclear test.
The adverse reaction would be too great. Kim wants sanctions relief and improved economic conditions in North Korea. A nuclear test would pull the rug out from under support for any favorable action.

At this moment it seems North Korea is still willing to negotiate with the US, even if with their recent missile test they are showing that they will drive a hard bargain. My guess is more missile tests to keep up the pressure until it becomes clear that the negotiations strategy isn't going to work.
By Accident!
Just a very rough base line. 6 nuclear tests in 12 years, and almost one third of the year gone.

Since 2006, North Korea has conducted six nuclear tests in 2006, 2009, 2013, 2016 (twice) and 2017 respectively. The reasons why there is no nuclear test after 2017 can be divided into two parts. First, was the suspend of further nuclear tests because its capabilities had been verified in earlier 2018 and; second, the interaction between DPRK and ROK during 2018 Winter Olympics in South Korea offered possibilities to softly dismantle North Koreaâs nuclear arsenal through dialogue (inter-Koreas) and meeting (Trump and Kim)
Doing this will stop all hope of North Korea making a deal with the West
Negotiations with the US will go nowhere. Kim Jong-un likely to restart as a means to apply pressure to Trump.

They probably don't need to test anymore, as they seem to have mastered the technology. So they would only do it for political reasons, and although their relationships with SK and the US seem to have turned a bit sour lately, I think they've got plenty of other ways to send a political message. Added some percentage points to account for the general unpredictability of NK.
Original facility collapsed. Will do another test when pushed into a corner/ another famine occurs and use it as leverage.

. The halt in nuclear testing is enough to give Trump the political points he craves. So Kim will not give up his nukes, but he is unlikely to conducts tests for fear of returning into Trumps black books.

They are awaiting the South China Sea out of the blue confrontation and then will jump in. Never forget; they are not idiots. They have ALREADY nuclear weapons. But....China can benefit on both sides and globally by promoting North Korea on economic forums by supporting relaxation of sanctions in exchange for wider cooperation with global powers.

North Korea benefits from the Trump Administration's negotiation tactics. Never before has a US president been so accommodating or attentive. ICBM and nuclear tests are intended to frighten, intimidate, and capture attention. Doing so before January 2020 might destabilize US support for Trump, thus jeopardizing North Korea's ability to negotiate on a world stage. This could ultimately mean significant issues within North Korea, where they are struggling for food and medicine that could be easily provided by a brokered partnership with South Korea and the west. Further, China is likely to want to improve North Korea's ability to trade with other global partners as a potential longer term method of avoiding the impact of future trade wars, so they are likely to push North Korea to act calmly rather than launching tests.
Just, please no.
Down from 7% due to passage of time.
Mostly quiet: https://beyondparallel.csis.org/yongbyon-nuclear-complex-normal-operations-with-low-level-activity/
Based on the breakdown in North Korean relations with the US and the south, I think the risk of provocations has increased.
It would mean that North Korea has given up on its encroachment policy fails
new ICBM test comes first. after that, we'll see.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-usa/third-summit-between-trump-and-north-koreas-kim-likely-no-date-set-u-s-official-idUSKBN1QS1QB?il=0
Outside view: 6 tests/13 years, 46% chance in a year: 35% until 1 Jan 2020
Unless the situation deteriorates badly and rapidly, any message from Kim to his vassal would be better sent by an ICBM test than by a nuclear one.

Reducing from 10% due to passage of time (-1%), and some further de-escalation (-2%): US-SK to "end large-scale military drills" (codenamed Foal Eagle & Key Resolve) [1]. Compare to 2018, when FE/KR still happened, but in reduced form [2].
Little Kim may be about to lose his bessie mate in the White House. DT would not come up with the goods, and may not be there much longer, and Kim needs to remind everyone why he's famous.
The Pyongyang Kid, like everyone else on the planet, is winning the propaganda war against The Leader Of The Free World. No particular reason for him to do this just yet.
Reducing from 4%.

My forecast was above 50% previously, so this is an adjustment downward. I don't want to read too much into Trump's talks, and it may even make a test more likely, not less, if they don't go well. However, I felt sheepish for being so far away from the consensus estimate. This is a tough one and January 1, 2020 is very far away for something like this.
No sense tweaking the nose right now.

The commander of U.S. forces in South Korea cited a âpalpableâ decline in tensions amid U.S.-North Korean peace talks but cautioned thereâs little evidence that Kim Jong Un is willing to give up his nuclear arsenal.

Depends on how the next meeting goes with North Korea and the United States. If there is a strong enough appearance of an upside to North Korea, that might be enough to get them to sign-on to a verifiable agreement.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-sanctions-un/north-korea-protecting-nuclear-missiles-u-n-monitors-say-ahead-of-summit-talks-idUSKCN1PU03G

Given the second US-NK summit is planning out in advance, and the recent progress in inter-Korean relations, it is unlikely that NK will relaunch their nuclear program any time soon, especially before the second Trump-Kim meeting. The second meeting is a critical point to say whether or not a deal could be made and carried out. The better deal NK makes (esp. in economic terms), the later they may delay their next nuclear test. NK economy cannot sustain much more sanction and this is likely the chance for Kim to become NK's Deng Xiaoping.
Kim will continue to lead M. Petits-Doigts down the garden path on the denuclearisation scam; this militates against his blowing up anything for a while.
Really holding pat here, but January has passed without a peep.

North Korea hasn't had any nuclear testing since mid 2017. Negotiations have come to a halt between the U.S. and North Korea on the issue of denuclearization. There may be a talk conducted between the two nations in February which will give us the latest insight on what North Korea is thinking if it occurs. Currently I asses that there won't be nuclear test conducted before January 2020 since nuclear testing has been dormant for some time.
This is not in his best interest before the summit in Q1; I will need to re-evaluate after the summit.

(repeating my forecast so that it updates the stats on my 'current forecasts' page) Can anyone explain why the current consensus has Mr Kim more likely to do a nuclear test than an ICBM test this year?
Smart money ranges from 0-10% with a low end bias. h/t @Anneinak for rationale.
North Korean diplomat is visiting U.S and talks of denuclearization will likely continue since the previous summit.

After a meeting between DJT with an envoy from DPRK, a second summit for February was announced. This is a change to the little progress in de-nuclearization negotiations. Anyway, KJU set conditions, that the US cannot (IMHO) meet, before DPRK de-nuclearization, neither KJU will do as it's key for his survival. At some point, DPRK will show power.

Reasons why not DPRK blew up its test site in their last test. It takes about a year to create a new test site. KJU declared in his NY speech that DPRK was not going to conduct additional tests Too provocative: will anger China & other regional powers Missile technology seems to be weaker (sub launches have been miserable failures) so that may be the direction of effort Costly! I see nothing to be gained in terms of international or domestic prestige
Ticking up - Irans failed test has me watching for stunt on NK's part. The CIA needs to send in the worm again...
Starting from the arbitrary date of 1 Jan 2001, NK has done 6 tests. So that's 1 every 3 years, or a 1/3 chance per year.

Tensions seem to be increasing as US is now saying Korea has not been taking any concrete steps to denuclearize. It feels like this adds to instability and makes a test more likely. A year feels like a very long time, and all that needs to happen is one test, so I'm continuing to move my forecast up.

Revising down based on some thinking around the impact of Chinese trade negotiations on their commitment to denuclearize NK. I'm hesitant to go too far since (for me) the logical step after developing weapon and missile capabilities is to incrementally increase the power of the bomb.

They really have nothing to win with this. They have already showed they have this capability. Showing it another time would not improve their position. Instead it would probably create anger and weaken their negotiating position.

Why wouldn't they just bide their time and quietly enhance their capabilities? It's not like conducting a test is likely to earn them sanctions relief. I also don't see how it would help them diplomatically.
Highly likely given conquest of DJT
Both US and NK leaders are nuts
Affirming. No place and no reason to do it.

This is a tough one with a lot of ways it could break based on a number of different possible narratives. I am inclined to believe NK will want to conduct an occassional test to remind negotiating counterparts that they are a serious threat and need to be negotiated with as such. However, I also think there's a fair amount to gain by holding off on those tests. The other thing I find persuassive against my original belief is that this question does not include ICBM tests, which seems like a more threatening test to conduct, while maintaining the narrative that NK is not actively testing nuclear weapons.
Trump has turned his back on NK because he is not getting what he wants. NK might test a nuke to give Trump second thoughts about its effect on the election.
Practice make prefect.
I think that China and US will manage sticks/carrots sufficiently well to dissuade kim jong un from this largely pointless action.
Depends on what happens with Trump
Trump.
POTUS approach has lost momentum and so sanctions will remain and N> Korea will become impatient again.
Kim canât help himself. He wants to be a major player on the world stage and knows nuclear capability is the only way that happens.
I firmly believe North Korea has way too much to lose by testing again. And far too much to gain if they negotiate with Trump.
China won't allow it
This is all a pause there will be no real deal with North Korea, Trump charisma will soon fade
They are already not living up to "agreement"

They will never give up their nukes. Their attitude is that it makes them ârespectedâ and feared. They will continue to prove their capability with underground tests. Hopefully their dynastic leadershipâs fear will diminish as years go by and nobody actually attacks them.
Is not clear what type of deal that trump will make with North Korea.. his charisma will not last long.
They want to continue to pretend they are denuclearizing
They want to use fear for power and status in the world. Hold us all hostage.

It depends how damaged the main research facility was in the explosion last year. That they will want to, is clear: Kim sees this as a virility symbol and one way in which North Korea can square up to the US and China. That they may wish to show that the facility loss was not as catastrophic as some have said, ditto: while if they were truly sabre-rattling it is true they'd need to demo an ICBM to reach the US, but you don't need one to reach Japan or China (or their Russian border, lets not forget). Against this is any 'peace dividend' Kim can see with South Korea because nuclear stuff is very, very expensive. Between now and 2020 is a long time in international relations. The South may have a change of government. In 2020 the US may. Kim may feel he needs to remind everyone how important he is, if the focus shifts.

North Korean nuclear weapons tests seem a good bit less likely to me than ICBM tests. Most assume that North Korea has atomic bombs but not Teller-Ulam style hydrogen bombs now, and having atomic weapons is the biggest component of deterrence at this point. Testing could show problems, and as long as they are fairly confident that the bombs would work, I don't see a clear benefit to testing unless they wish to get full-blown hydrogen bombs. It seems like delivery systems would need more testing at this point.

Updating based on the New Year's Speech. Kim's note seemed defiant, but I thought one analyst put it well when he said Kim's posture may be strategic positioning in the spat between the US & China (https://www.38north.org/2019/01/rfrank010219/). Could this mean that Kim will be "incentivized" by China to discontinue nuclear tests? I could see it going either way and need further analysis.

Mr Kim's new year's address makes it clear he does not wish to upset the peace process with North America. https://www.38north.org/2019/01/rcarlin010319/ âIt is the invariable stand of our Party and the government of our Republic and my firm will to establish a new bilateral relationship that meets the demand of the new era as clarified in the June 12 DPRK-US Joint Statement, build a lasting and durable peace regime and advance towards complete denuclearization.â ...Kim claimed that as evidence of the Northâs commitment to the above goals: âAccordingly, we declared at home and abroad that we would neither make and test nuclear weapons any longer nor use and proliferate them, and we have taken various practical measures.â My sense is it would take more than a year of stalemate, inaction by NK and severe sanctions by US for the situation to re-escalate to the point of resuming tests. There are many secondary risks, which I assess/guess at less than 5%
They haven't shown any signs of dismantling their facilities. They can do this very easily as a show of force to gain some sort of percieved advantage.

https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-46719057 Like practically everybody else in charge of anything anywhere on the planet, The Pyongyang Kid is better at this game than The Leader Of The Free World. The latter is likely to do something impulsive and unhelpful, leaving Kim to decide how hard to push. I think an ICBM test is likelier than a nuke, but bumping this up a bit just in case.

From 2006-2017 the North performed 6 nuclear tests. Whether you assume they only have the resources/capacity to test 1 per year or 2 per year, then the base probability would be 27% or 55%. Iâm inclined to go with 55% since capabilities grow over time and they did 2 in 2016.
they've done 6 tests over the last 13 years https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_nuclear_weapons_tests_of_North_Korea
Not at this point. Though depending on how dialogue progresses for the next couple months, there may be a resurgence of testing in the spring.
Based on current communications with North Korea it seems less likely. Forecast is subject to change based on negotiations/talks
Yes. The nuclear option is an insurance for Kim Govt, because its main hostile bidder is not America but China. Kim fears its big, close, red, chinese neighbor more than USA.
they would be stupid to do so and they arent stupid
Basing on https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/795059
The peninsula is on the way to peace.
Kim Jung Un has shown he is afraid of Trump.
Increased due to nk anger over sanctions this week

I think that DJT gave KJ-U what he really wanted and that was validation by a sitting US President, which is why the tensions have seemed to have cooled, especially compared to prior years. That said, nothing substantial has been signed or agreed to, so we could easily be back to a higher aggravated NK.
Kim Jong doesnât listen and avoids reality.
Remote chance
Because the deal with trump was meaningless and has given them little - theyâve moved barely none on denuclearisation and this is the only strong hand Kim has - heâll turn to it again
Scary but likely scenario
Cultural nose snub and continued posturing to enforce his/military's control over the country.

Kim understands that he needs support of the world to feed his people. It seems like he has realized that he wants to leave a good legacy behind him and most of the dictators dont survive in current world. US China relations will be a major factor. Any fallout of US and China could potentially trigger north korea getting backing of China to develop the weapons again and do the tests. Also, in case Kim loses support in his inner circle then he might panic and do strange things.

North Korea/DPRK has conducted nuclear tests before and could do so again. It conducted its sixth nuclear test on 3 September 2017, stating it had tested a thermonuclear weapon (hydrogen bomb). Kemp, Ted (3 September 2017). "North Korea hydrogen bomb: Read the full announcement from Pyongyang". CNBC News. DPRK now has the capability. Since SEP17, it has not conducted another test because of US pressure to stop their program. It is currently in KJU's best interest to hold off on nuclear tests to gain concessions from the US and international community. At this time, there are no indicators for additional tests. Because 1JAN20 is nearly 14 months from now, chances that something happens between now and then that causes KJU to conduct additional tests to re-energize negotiations is relatively high at approximately 45%.
As DPRK becomes less a threat, Kim Jung Uh must throw another temper tantrum.
Regain negotiating power

Seems unlikely considering current North Korean relations with the US and South Korea. Aside from diplomacy, North Korea has already demonstrated all the capacity it needs so I'm not sure what benefit the country has to gain.
They have already demonstrated the capability, future public testing would likely be detrimental to their goals. I wouldn't rule out secret testing.
I think this is somewhat more likely than the ICBM test, as this does not require testing outside of DPRK territory. Hence, it doesn't have the visuals that launching an ICBM has.

It is very unlikely. The ICBM is more likely than Nuclear. Read my other post. https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1053-will-north-korea-launch-an-intercontinental-ballistic-missile-icbm-before-1-january-2020
Why in the world wouldn't they? They can do it and they have not destroyed their capabilities at all.
NOrth Korea is determined to convince Trump that they are serious

Signed agreement with Trump which generates some kind of international pressure and expectation as well as some threat from U.S. and other actors if carried out. Disincentives there. But agreement was flimsy and NK hasnât been too sensitive to international community pressure in past.
No need for this, really. An ICBM launch, if one occurs, should send an adequate signal.
They do not need to.

International Observation On October 31, 2018, Kim Min-ki, a lawmaker in South Korea's ruling Democratic Party, stated that now defunct Punggye-ri was among other nuclear and missile test sites which had been observed by officials from South Korea's National Intelligence Service and that it was now ready for planned international inspection https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punggye-ri_Nuclear_Test_Site

Where would they do it? I think the question now is to show that they can deliver the nukes they have to a distant target. So, if they go this route, it will be missile launches and not nuclear tests.
the destruction of North Koreaâs only known nuclear test site.

The question doesn't specify whether merely the claim of a test by North Korea counts, or if only tests verified by an outside government count. If it's only verified tests, then verified by whom? I wonder if the question would resolve as 'yes' if say Japan verified a test but the US said it's inconclusive. I'm going to assume that only verified tests count, and hope that outside governments are in agreement with each other.
Not much chance of this. They have established their capabilities for all to see, so little need for additional testing.
